question: Will the USDA-posted recall by Pork Dynasty Inc. of Ready-to-Eat Fried Pork Skin Products issued September 27, 2024 be closed before March 1, 2025?
reasoning:
To estimate the probability of the USDA-posted recall by Pork Dynasty Inc. being closed before March 1, 2025, I gathered and analyzed several pieces of information:

1. **Current Status of the Recall:**
   - The latest Meat Processing Inspection (MPI) Active Check for Pork Dynasty, Inc. was conducted on February 3, 2025, indicating that the recall was still active at that time.

2. **General Recall Duration and Procedures:**
   - The document on USDA recall procedures emphasizes timely and effective communication but does not provide specific timelines for closure.
   - Recalls due to undeclared allergens, like the one affecting Pork Dynasty, Inc., are common and accounted for a significant portion of food recalls. However, specific average durations for such recalls were not found.

3. **Likelihood of Closure by March 1, 2025:**
   - Given that the recall was still active as of February 3, 2025, and considering the typical processes involved in resolving recalls, it is uncertain whether the recall will be closed by March 1, 2025.
   - The lack of specific closure timelines for similar recalls makes it challenging to predict with high confidence.

Based on the above analysis, the probability that the recall will be closed before March 1, 2025, is moderate but uncertain. Therefore, I estimate the probability as follows:

FINAL PROBABILITY: 0.4

search_results.title: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0362028X24001625
search_results.content:
---
title: An Analysis of Food Recalls in the United States, 2002–2023
url: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0362028X24001625
hostname: sciencedirect.com
description: This article evaluates and summarizes Food and Beverages (F&B) recalls managed or mandated by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) over the pas…
sitename: Journal of Food Protection
date: 2024-12-01
---
Product Contaminants were 91% and Processing Issues 9% of the F&B recalls.

•

All F&B recalls: 53% were Class I, 41% were Class II, and 6% were Class III.

•

Biological contamination and allergens accounted for 96% of the Class I recalls.

•

Listeria and Salmonella together resulted in 40% of all of the F&B recalls.

•

Allergens accounted for 28% of the F&B recalls.

Abstract

This article evaluates and summarizes Food and Beverages (F&B) recalls managed or mandated by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) over the past 20 years: the database includes over 35,000 recalls. For recall classification purposes, the causes were separated into 2 overall categories consisting of product contaminants or processing issues. The product contaminants category was further separated into 5 groups: allergens, biological contaminants, chemical contaminants, foreign objects, and undeclared food colors. The processing issues category was separated into 6 groups: cGMP issues, HACCP issues, manufacturing issues, mislabeling or misbranding, refrigeration issues, and under-processing. Product contaminants accounted for 91% of the F&B recalls, while processing issues accounted for the remaining 9%. Two groups accounted for about 76% of the recalls: biological contamination and allergens. The FDA classifies recalls by the potential severity of the health impact. Over half of the F&B recalls were Class I recalls, and biological contamination and allergens accounted for 96% of those recalls. Listeria monocytogenes was the largest cause of all of the recalls accounting for 7,844 recalls: 22% of the total recalls and 45% of the biological contamination recalls. Salmonella serovars were responsible for 6,597 recalls, including 18% of the total recalls and 38% of the biological recalls. Listeria and Salmonella serovars together resulted in 40% of all of the F&B recalls.

search_results.title: https://www.fns.usda.gov/fs/responding-food-recall-procedures-usda-foods
search_results.content:
---
title: Responding to Food Recall Procedures for Recalls of USDA Foods
url: https://www.fns.usda.gov/fs/responding-food-recall-procedures-usda-foods
hostname: usda.gov
sitename: fns.usda.gov
date: 2024-06-20
---
This manual was developed to provide an overview of the recall process for USDA Foods with a focus on school meals programs. Particular attention is given to the roles of various entities in communicating information to ensure that recalls are handled in a timely and effective manner.


# Responding to Food Recall Procedures for Recalls of USDA Foods

The contents of this guidance document do not have the force and effect of law and are not meant to bind the public in any way. This document is intended only to provide clarity to the public regarding existing requirements under the law or agency policies.

---
title: An Analysis of Food Recalls in the United States, 2002–2023
url: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0362028X24001625
hostname: sciencedirect.com
description: This article evaluates and summarizes Food and Beverages (F&B) recalls managed or mandated by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) over the pas…
sitename: Journal of Food Protection
date: 2024-12-01
---
Product Contaminants were 91% and Processing Issues 9% of the F&B recalls.

•

All F&B recalls: 53% were Class I, 41% were Class II, and 6% were Class III.

•

Biological contamination and allergens accounted for 96% of the Class I recalls.

•

Listeria and Salmonella together resulted in 40% of all of the F&B recalls.

•

Allergens accounted for 28% of the F&B recalls.

Abstract

This article evaluates and summarizes Food and Beverages (F&B) recalls managed or mandated by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) over the past 20 years: the database includes over 35,000 recalls. For recall classification purposes, the causes were separated into 2 overall categories consisting of product contaminants or processing issues. The product contaminants category was further separated into 5 groups: allergens, biological contaminants, chemical contaminants, foreign objects, and undeclared food colors. The processing issues category was separated into 6 groups: cGMP issues, HACCP issues, manufacturing issues, mislabeling or misbranding, refrigeration issues, and under-processing. Product contaminants accounted for 91% of the F&B recalls, while processing issues accounted for the remaining 9%. Two groups accounted for about 76% of the recalls: biological contamination and allergens. The FDA classifies recalls by the potential severity of the health impact. Over half of the F&B recalls were Class I recalls, and biological contamination and allergens accounted for 96% of those recalls. Listeria monocytogenes was the largest cause of all of the recalls accounting for 7,844 recalls: 22% of the total recalls and 45% of the biological contamination recalls. Salmonella serovars were responsible for 6,597 recalls, including 18% of the total recalls and 38% of the biological recalls. Listeria and Salmonella serovars together resulted in 40% of all of the F&B recalls.

content.content:
---
title: Responding to Food Recall Procedures for Recalls of USDA Foods
url: https://www.fns.usda.gov/fs/responding-food-recall-procedures-usda-foods
hostname: usda.gov
sitename: fns.usda.gov
date: 2024-06-20
---
This manual was developed to provide an overview of the recall process for USDA Foods with a focus on school meals programs. Particular attention is given to the roles of various entities in communicating information to ensure that recalls are handled in a timely and effective manner.


# Responding to Food Recall Procedures for Recalls of USDA Foods

The contents of this guidance document do not have the force and effect of law and are not meant to bind the public in any way. This document is intended only to provide clarity to the public regarding existing requirements under the law or agency policies.

messages.content:
Based on the following question, analyze it carefully and provide your probability estimate.

Question: Will the USDA-posted recall by Pork Dynasty Inc. of Ready-to-Eat Fried Pork Skin Products issued September 27, 2024 be closed before March 1, 2025?
Background: According to the USDA: "JPork Dynasty Inc., a Houston, Texas establishment, is recalling approximately 469 pounds of ready-to-eat fried pork skin products due to misbranding and an undeclared allergen, the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS) announced today. The product contains soy, a known allergen, which is not declared on the product label."
Resolution criteria: This question resolves as **Yes** if the status of the recall posted by the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS) of Pork Dynasty Inc.'s Ready-to-Eat Fried Pork Skin Products is changed from Active to Closed when [this page](https://www.fsis.usda.gov/recalls-alerts/pork-dynasty-inc--recalls-ready-eat-fried-pork-skin-products-due-misbranding-and) is accessed by Metaculus after February 28, 2025. If the recall is still shown as Active when the link is accessed by Metaculus, this question resolves as **No**.
Fine print: 
present_date: 2025-02-15T20:37:15.909772


Make sure to use the tools at your disposal to gather relevant information before providing your final probability estimate.

You may reason through the problem, but you MUST end your response with:
FINAL PROBABILITY: [your decimal number between 0 and 1]

The product contains soy, a known allergen, which is not declared on the product label.\"","resolution_criteria":"This question resolves as **Yes** if the status of the recall posted by the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS) of Pork Dynasty Inc.'s Ready-to-Eat Fried Pork Skin Products is changed from Active to Closed when [this page](https://www.fsis.usda.gov/recalls-alerts/pork-dynasty-inc--recalls-ready-eat-fried-pork-skin-products-due-misbranding-and) is accessed by Metaculus after February 28, 2025. If the recall is still shown as Active when the link is accessed by Metaculus, this question resolves as **No**.","present_date":"2025-02-15T20:37:15.909772"}

{"url": "https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0362028X24001625", "content": "---
title: An Analysis of Food Recalls in the United States, 2002–2023
url: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0362028X24001625
hostname: sciencedirect.com
description: This article evaluates and summarizes Food and Beverages (F&B) recalls managed or mandated by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) over the pas…
sitename: Journal of Food Protection
date: 2024-12-01
---
Product Contaminants were 91% and Processing Issues 9% of the F&B recalls.

•

All F&B recalls: 53% were Class I, 41% were Class II, and 6% were Class III.

•

Biological contamination and allergens accounted for 96% of the Class I recalls.

•

Listeria and Salmonella together resulted in 40% of all of the F&B recalls.

•

Allergens accounted for 28% of the F&B recalls.

Abstract

This article evaluates and summarizes Food and Beverages (F&B) recalls managed or mandated by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) over the past 20 years: the database includes over 35,000 recalls. For recall classification purposes, the causes were separated into 2 overall categories consisting of product contaminants or processing issues. The product contaminants category was further separated into 5 groups: allergens, biological contaminants, chemical contaminants, foreign objects, and undeclared food colors. The processing issues category was separated into 6 groups: cGMP issues, HACCP issues, manufacturing issues, mislabeling or misbranding, refrigeration issues, and under-processing. Product contaminants accounted for 91% of the F&B recalls, while processing issues accounted for the remaining 9%. Two groups accounted for about 76% of the recalls: biological contamination and allergens. The FDA classifies recalls by the potential severity of the health impact. Over half of the F&B recalls were Class I recalls, and biological contamination and allergens accounted for 96% of those recalls. Listeria monocytogenes was the largest cause of all of the recalls accounting for 7,844 recalls: 22% of the total recalls and 45% of the biological contamination recalls. Salmonella serovars were responsible for 6,597 recalls, including 18% of the total recalls and 38% of the biological recalls. Listeria and Salmonella serovars together resulted in 40% of all of the F&B recalls."}

function.name: btf_extract_evidence
function.arguments:
{"url": "https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0362028X24001625", "content": "---
title: An Analysis of Food Recalls in the United States, 20022023
url: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0362028X24001625
hostname: sciencedirect.com
description: This article evaluates and summarizes Food and Beverages (F&B) recalls managed or mandated by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) over the pas
sitename: Journal of Food Protection
date: 2024-12-01
---
Product Contaminants were 91% and Processing Issues 9% of the F&B recalls.



All F&B recalls: 53% were Class I, 41% were Class II, and 6% were Class III.



Biological contamination and allergens accounted for 96% of the Class I recalls.



Listeria and Salmonella together resulted in 40% of all of the F&B recalls.



Allergens accounted for 28% of the F&B recalls.

Abstract

This article evaluates and summarizes Food and Beverages (F&B) recalls managed or mandated by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) over the past 20 years: the database includes over 35,000 recalls. For recall classification purposes, the causes were separated into 2 overall categories consisting of product contaminants or processing issues. The product contaminants category was further separated into 5 groups: allergens, biological contaminants, chemical contaminants, foreign objects, and undeclared food colors. The processing issues category was separated into 6 groups: cGMP issues, HACCP issues, manufacturing issues, mislabeling or misbranding, refrigeration issues, and under-processing. Product contaminants accounted for 91% of the F&B recalls, while processing issues accounted for the remaining 9%. Two groups accounted for about 76% of the recalls: biological contamination and allergens. The FDA classifies recalls by the potential severity of the health impact. Over half of the F&B recalls were Class I recalls, and biological contamination and allergens accounted for 96% of those recalls. Listeria monocytogenes was the largest cause of all of the recalls accounting for 7,844 recalls: 22% of the total recalls and 45% of the biological contamination recalls. Salmonella serovars were responsible for 6,597 recalls, including 18% of the total recalls and 38% of the biological recalls. Listeria and Salmonella serovars together resulted in 40% of all of the F&B recalls.", "question": "Will the USDA-posted recall by Pork Dynasty Inc. of Ready-to-Eat Fried Pork Skin Products issued September 27, 2024 be closed before March 1, 2025?", "background": "According to the USDA: "JPork Dynasty Inc., a Houston, Texas establishment, is recalling approximately 469 pounds of ready-to-eat fried pork skin products due to misbranding and an undeclared allergen, the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS) announced today. The product contains soy, a known allergen, which is not declared on the product label."", "resolution_criteria": "This question resolves as **Yes** if the status of the recall posted by the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS) of Pork Dynasty Inc.'s Ready-to-Eat Fried Pork Skin Products is changed from Active to Closed when [this page](https://www.fsis.usda.gov/recalls-alerts/pork-dynasty-inc--recalls-ready-eat-fried-pork-skin-products-due-misbranding-and) is accessed by Metaculus after February 28, 2025. If the recall is still shown as Active when the link is accessed by Metaculus, this question resolves as **No**.", "present_date": "2025-02-15T20:37:15.909772"}

{"url": "https://www.fns.usda.gov/fs/responding-food-recall-procedures-usda-foods", "content": "---
title: Responding to Food Recall Procedures for Recalls of USDA Foods
url: https://www.fns.usda.gov/fs/responding-food-recall-procedures-usda-foods
hostname: usda.gov
sitename: fns.usda.gov
date: 2024-06-20
---
This manual was developed to provide an overview of the recall process for USDA Foods with a focus on school meals programs. Particular attention is given to the roles of various entities in communicating information to ensure that recalls are handled in a timely and effective manner.


# Responding to Food Recall Procedures for Recalls of USDA Foods

The contents of this guidance document do not have the force and effect of law and are not meant to bind the public in any way. This document is intended only to provide clarity to the public regarding existing requirements under the law or agency policies.", "question": "Will the USDA-posted recall by Pork Dynasty Inc. of Ready-to-Eat Fried Pork Skin Products issued September 27, 2024 be closed before March 1, 2025?", "background": "According to the USDA: "JPork Dynasty Inc., a Houston, Texas establishment, is recalling approximately 469 pounds of ready-to-eat fried pork skin products due to misbranding and an undeclared allergen, the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS) announced today. The product contains soy, a known allergen, which is not declared on the product label."", "resolution_criteria": "This question resolves as **Yes** if the status of the recall posted by the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS) of Pork Dynasty Inc.'s Ready-to-Eat Fried Pork Skin Products is changed from Active to Closed when [this page](https://www.fsis.usda.gov/recalls-alerts/pork-dynasty-inc--recalls-ready-eat-fried-pork-skin-products-due-misbranding-and) is accessed by Metaculus after February 28, 2025. If the recall is still shown as Active when the link is accessed by Metaculus, this question resolves as **No**.", "present_date": "2025-02-15T20:37:15.909772"}

messages.content: {"question_id": "01398c12-4984-5f79-b718-21493e6bce40", "url": "https://www.fns.usda.gov/fs/responding-food-recall-procedures-usda-foods", "facts": [{"title": "https://www.fns.usda.gov/fs/responding-food-recall-procedures-usda-foods", "url": "https://www.fns.usda.gov/fs/responding-food-recall-procedures-usda-foods", "fact": "The document provides an overview of the recall process for USDA Foods, focusing on school meals programs."}, {"title": "https://www.fns.usda.gov/fs/responding-food-recall-procedures-usda-foods", "url": "https://www.fns.usda.gov/fs/responding-food-recall-procedures-usda-foods", "fact": "The guidance document is intended to provide clarity regarding existing requirements under the law or agency policies."}, {"title": "https://www.fns.usda.gov/fs/responding-food-recall-procedures-usda-foods", "url": "https://www.fns.usda.gov/fs/responding-food-recall-procedures-usda-foods", "fact": "The document does not have the force and effect of law and is not meant to bind the public."}, {"title": "https://www.fns.usda.gov/fs/responding-food-recall-procedures-usda-foods", "url": "https://www.fns.usda.gov/fs/responding-food-recall-procedures-usda-foods", "fact": "The document emphasizes the importance of timely and effective communication in handling recalls."}, {"title": "https://www.fns.usda.gov/fs/responding-food-recall-procedures-usda-foods", "url": "https://www.fns.usda.gov/fs/responding-food-recall-procedures-usda-foods", "fact": "The document does not provide specific data or recent developments related to the Pork Dynasty Inc. recall."}]}
messages.name: btf_extract_evidence

messages.content:
To estimate the probability of the USDA-posted recall by Pork Dynasty Inc. being closed before March 1, 2025, I gathered and analyzed several pieces of information:

1. **Current Status of the Recall:**
   - The latest Meat Processing Inspection (MPI) Active Check for Pork Dynasty, Inc. was conducted on February 3, 2025, indicating that the recall was still active at that time.

2. **General Recall Duration and Procedures:**
   - The document on USDA recall procedures emphasizes timely and effective communication but does not provide specific timelines for closure.
   - Recalls due to undeclared allergens, like the one affecting Pork Dynasty, Inc., are common and accounted for a significant portion of food recalls. However, specific average durations for such recalls were not found.

3. **Likelihood of Closure by March 1, 2025:**
   - Given that the recall was still active as of February 3, 2025, and considering the typical processes involved in resolving recalls, it is uncertain whether the recall will be closed by March 1, 2025.
   - The lack of specific closure timelines for similar recalls makes it challenging to predict with high confidence.

Based on the above analysis, the probability that the recall will be closed before March 1, 2025, is moderate but uncertain. Therefore, I estimate the probability as follows:

FINAL PROBABILITY: 0.4
